qas.question: What is generally used as starch in most beer?
What kind of container is partially germinated grain dried in?
What happens to grain when it is soaked in water?
What does a grains starch become after an is malted?
What material does the flavour source in beer provide?
What is the most common enzyme source used in beer?
What is malted by soaking it in a kiln?

plausible_answers.text: different colours of malt from the same grain

qas.question: What do different roasting sugars produce?

context: The starch source in a beer provides the <b5_0>fermentable material<b5_0/> and is a key determinant of the strength and flavour of the beer. The most common starch source used in beer is <a0_0><b6_0>malted grain<b6_0/><a0_0/>. <b7_0>Grain<b7_0/> is malted <a1_0>by soaking it in water<a1_0/>, allowing it to begin <a3_0>germination<a3_0/>, and then drying the partially germinated grain in <a2_0>a kiln<a2_0/>. Malting grain produces enzymes that convert starches in the grain into <a4_0>fermentable sugars<a4_0/>. Different roasting times and temperatures are used to produce <b8_0>different colours of malt from the same grain<b8_0/>. Darker malts will produce darker beers.
